moves.1. e4: This game features an early blunder by white, and a recovery leading to a fairly quick victory for white.
moves.1... e6 2. d4 d5 3. e5 c5 4. c3 Qb6 5. a: The French opening, played unreflectively by both parties. I opted for a3 without much thought, and relying heavily on a games database. Thinking on my own, I may have played Ng3 instead.
moves.5... Nc6 6. Nf3 cxd4 7. Nxd4: This was the blunder. I should have taken with the pawn.
moves.7... Bc5: No way to add a third defender to the knight. Only option is to go down fighting.
moves.8. Nxc6 Bxf2+: And lose a pawn. The king now has to give up castling rights. Virtually none of the minor pieces are developed. At this point I considered resigning, but somehow or other, continued playing.
moves.9. Kd2: Trying to move the king to a safe position.
moves.9... bxc6 10. Kc2 Ne7: Perhaps black should have pressed his advantage by attacking the e5 square with f6. It removes a strategically placed pawn and begins to open up a file for his light square bishop.
moves.11. Bd3: Protecting the king and connecting queen and rook.
moves.11... Ba6: Not sure what black's plan is. My only concern is to get the knight and bishop out of their starting positions to connect the rooks.
moves.12. Bf4: This pawn would prove very dangerous for black.
moves.12... Bxd3+ 13. Qxd3: This proved a poor exchange for black. It enables white to develop the queen and renders his connected queen and bishop a little ineffective.
moves.13... Ng6 14. Bg3 Bxg3 15. Qxg3: This series of exchanges proved favourable for white, enabling the development of his queen. The central pawn pivots the whole series of exchanges.
moves.16. b4: This pawn defensive structure is extremely effective.
moves.16... c5 17. Nd2: At last developing the knight and connecting the rooks. The defensive pawn structure looks strong, despite the additional attacker.
moves.17... d4: Black tries attacking the base of the pawn structure. However, white can safely ignore the threat.
moves.18. Nc4: Taking advantage of black's pawn advance and threatening the queen, and protecting the e5 pawn. It seems that this was an important square.
moves.18... Qc6: Probable a good spot to retreat to, threatening a check on a4
moves.19. Nd6+: Now the value of the advanced central pawn can be seen.
moves.19... Ke7: Seems a good move, connecting his rooks.
moves.20. Qg5+ Kf8: Losing the connected rooks. Perhaps Kd7 would have been better.
moves.21. Rhf1: Threatening pawn recapture with a powerful check.
moves.21... Nxe5: At last he takes the pawn, but too late. White has already developed a strong attack.
moves.22. Qxe5 Qxg2+: Looks like a devastating move for black, but the threat to f7 was overlooked.
moves.23. Kb3 Qd2: Hoping for a powerful check in the next move, but giving white time to finish the game.
